xxl.io
Class BlockFileContainer

java.lang.Object
  |
  +--xxl.collections.Container
        |
        +--xxl.io.BlockFileContainer
Direct Known Subclasses:
MultiBlockContainer
public class BlockFileContainer
extends Container

This class provides a container that is able to store blocks in a file.

The container depends on three files: a container file, a fat file and a freeList file.
The container file is used for storing the blocks of this container. In addition, the offset of an block in the container file determines the id of the block in this container. Every block stored in the container file takes blockSize bytes, therefore blocks that contains more than blockSize bytes cannot be stored in this container. The fat file stores a bit table that shows the allocation of the container file. In order to store this table, eight bits are joined to an int value. For this reason the nth bit of the fat file is stored as the (n%8)th bit of the (n/8)th int value of the fat file. The freeList file stores the offsets of removed blocks. Whenever a block should be written to this container, the freeList file is checked, whether there are empty blocks in the container file. If the freeList file contains offsets of removed blocks the new block will be stored in an empty space of the container file, else the container file will be enlarged.

Example usage (1). 

     // create a new block file container with ...

     BlockFileContainer container = new BlockFileContainer(

         // files having the file name "BlockFileContainer"

         "BlockFileContainer",

         // a block size of 4 bytes (size of a serialized integer)

         4
     );

     // insert 10 blocks containing the integers between 0 and 9

     for (int i = 0; i < 10; i++) {

         // create a new block

         Block block = new Block(4);

         // catch IOExceptions

         try {

             // write the value of i to the block

             block.dataOutputStream().write(i);
         }
         catch (IOException ioe) {
             System.out.println("An I/O error occured.");
         }

         // insert the block into the block file container

         container.insert(block);
     }

     // get the ids of all elements in the container

     Iterator iterator = container.ids();

     // print all elements of the container

     while (iterator.hasNext()) {

         // get the block from the container

         Block block = (Block)container.get(iterator.next());

         // catch IOExceptions

         try {

             // print the data of the block

             System.out.println(block.dataInputStream().read());
         }
         catch (IOException ioe) {
             System.out.println("An I/O error occured.");
         }
     }

     // close the open container and clear its file after use

     container.close();
     container.clear();

See Also:
Container, IOException, Iterator, NoSuchElementException, RandomAccessFile, WrappingRuntimeException

Field Detail

prefix

protected String prefix
The name for the files of this container. The file names of the three files a block file container consists of differ only in their file extensions.

container

protected RandomAccessFile container
The container file of this container. The container file is used for storing the blocks of this container. In addition, the offset of an block in the container file determines the id of the block in this container. The name of the container file is determined by the String prefix and the file extension .ctr.

fat

protected RandomAccessFile fat
The fat file of this container. The fat file stores a bit table that shows the allocation of the container file. In order to store this table, eight bits are joined to an int value. For this reason the nth bit of the fat file is stored as the (n%8)th bit of the (n/8)th int value of the fat file. The name of the fat file is determined by the String prefix and the file extension .fat.

freeList

protected RandomAccessFile freeList
The freeList file of this container. The freeList file stores the offsets of removed blocks. Whenever a block should be written to this container, the freeList file is checked, whether there are empty blocks in the container file. If the freeList file contains offsets of removed blocks the new block will be stored in an empty space of the container file, else the container file will be enlarged. The name of the freeList file is determined by the String prefix and the file extension .flt.

blockSize

protected int blockSize
The size reserved for storing a block in this container. Every block stored in the container file takes blockSize bytes, therefore blocks that contains more than blockSize bytes cannot be stored in this container.

size

protected int size
The number of blocks stored in this container.

maxOffset

protected long maxOffset
The maximum offset of this container. The offset is given by the highest possible offset of a block in the container file.
Constructor Detail

BlockFileContainer

public BlockFileContainer(String prefix,
                          int blockSize)
Constructs an empty BlockFileContainer that is able to store blocks with a maximum size of blockSize bytes. The given String prefix specifies the names of the files the are used for storing the elements of the container. When using existing files to store the container their data will be overwritten.
Parameters:
prefix - specifies the names of the files the container consists of.
blockSize - the size reserved for storing a block in the container file.

BlockFileContainer

public BlockFileContainer(String prefix)
Constructs a BlockFileContainer that consists of existing files given by the specified file name. Every information the container needs will be taken from the fat file.
Parameters:
prefix - specifies the names of the files the container consists of.
Method Detail

open

protected void open()
Opens the files of this container and restores the state of this container. This method expects the serialized state of the container at the end of the fat file. After restoring the state of the container, the serialized data is removed from the fat file.

objectIdConverter

public Converter objectIdConverter()
Returns a converter for the ids generated by this container. A converter transforms an object to its byte representation and vice versa - also known as serialization in Java.
Because of using the offset in the container file (long value) as id, this method always returns a LongConverter.
Overrides:
objectIdConverter in class Container
Returns:
a converter for serializing the identifiers of the container.

blockSize

public int blockSize()
Returns the size reserved for storing a block in this container. Every block stored in the container file takes blockSize bytes, therefore blocks that contains more than blockSize bytes cannot be stored in this container.
Returns:
the size reserved for storing a block in this container.

reset

public void reset()
Resets this container and any files associated with it.
This implementation sets the length of the associated files to 0. Thereafter the size and maximum offset of this container are corrected.

clear

public void clear()
Removes all elements from the Container. After a call of this method, size() will return 0.
This implementation only calls the reset method.
Overrides:
clear in class Container

close

public void close()
Closes the Container and releases its associated files. But before closing the fat file, the serialized state of this container must be appended. Therefore, the values of the fields size, blockSize and maxOffset are append to the fat file. A closed container can be implicit reopened by a consecutive call to one of its methods.
Overrides:
close in class Container

contains

public boolean contains(Object id)
Returns true if the container contains a block for the identifier id.
This implementation checks whether the fat files contains an entry for the offset specified by id.
Overrides:
contains in class Container
Parameters:
id - identifier of the block.
Returns:
true if the container contains a block for the specified identifier.

get

public Object get(Object id,
                  boolean unfix)
           throws NoSuchElementException
Returns the block associated to the identifier id. An exception is thrown when the desired block is not found. If unfix, the block can be removed from the underlying buffer. Otherwise (!unfix), the block has to be kept in the buffer.
In this implementation the parameter unfix has no function because the container is unbuffered.
Overrides:
get in class Container
Parameters:
id - identifier of the block.
unfix - signals whether the object can be removed from the underlying buffer.
Returns:
the block associated to the specified identifier.
Throws:
NoSuchElementException - if the desired block is not found.

ids

public Iterator ids()
Returns an iterator that deliver the identifiers of all blocks of the container.
Overrides:
ids in class Container
Returns:
an iterator of object identifiers.

insert

public Object insert(Object object,
                     boolean unfix)
Inserts a new block into the container and returns the offset of the block in the container file as unique identifier. Whenever a block should be inserted into this container, the freeList file is checked, whether there are empty blocks in the container file. If the freeList file contains offsets of removed blocks the new block will be stored in an empty space of the container file, else the container file will be enlarged. The parameter unfix has no function because this container is unbuffered.
Overrides:
insert in class Container
Parameters:
object - the new block that should be inserted into the container.
unfix - signals a buffered container whether the block can be removed from the underlying buffer.
Returns:
the identifier of the block.

remove

public void remove(Object id)
            throws NoSuchElementException
Removes the block with identifier id. An exception is thrown when a block with an identifier id is not in the container. After a call of remove() all the iterators (and cursors) can be in an invalid state.
This implementation clears the entry for the block in the fat file and adds id to the freeList file.
Overrides:
remove in class Container
Parameters:
id - an identifier of a block.
Throws:
NoSuchElementException - if a block with an identifier id is not in the container.

size

public int size()
Returns the number of elements of the container.
Overrides:
size in class Container
Returns:
the number of elements.

unfix

public void unfix(Object id)
           throws NoSuchElementException
Unfixes the block with identifier id. This method throws an exception when no element with an identifier id is in the container. After one call of unfix the buffer is allowed to remove the block (although the block has been fixed more than once).
This implementation does nothing else than throwing an exception when no element with an identifier id is in the container.
Overrides:
unfix in class Container
Parameters:
id - identifier of a block that should be unfixed in the buffer.
Throws:
NoSuchElementException - if no element with an identifier id is in the container.

update

public void update(Object id,
                   Object object,
                   boolean unfix)
            throws NoSuchElementException
Overwrites an existing (id,*)-element by (id, object). This method throws an exception if a block with an identifier id does not exist in the container. The parameter unfix has no function because this container is unbuffered.
Overrides:
update in class Container
Parameters:
id - identifier of the element.
object - the new block that should be associated to id.
unfix - signals a buffered container whether the block can be removed from the underlying buffer.
Throws:
NoSuchElementException - if a block with an identifier id does not exist in the container.

main

public static void main(String[] args)
The main method contains some examples how to use a BlockFileContainer. It can also be used to test the functionality of a BlockFileContainer.
Parameters:
args - array of String arguments. It can be used to submit parameters when the main method is called.
